title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON – In a defensive struggle that defined an era, the Indiana Pacers grinded out an 87-80 victory over the Houston Rockets. But this game will be remembered not for the final score, but for the singular, historic performance of Indiana’s Reggie Miller, who authored a masterpiece for the ages.

Miller was simply unguardable, erupting for a career-high and franchise-record 57 points. He was a flurry of motion, a blur of orange and blue, slicing through the Rockets’ defense with an astonishing efficiency. His signature catch-and-shoot threes fell with ruthless consistency, while his relentless drives to the basket drew fouls and broke the spirit of the home team. The Houston defense, anchored by the great Hakeem Olajuwon, had no answer. Miller’s 57 not only carried his team but accounted for a staggering 65.5% of the entire Pacers’ offensive output.

While Miller’s scoring was otherworldly, the game was a rock fight otherwise. Houston’s Charles Barkley fought valiantly, pulling down a game-high 21 rebounds, but the Rockets’ offense sputtered. Clyde Drexler was held to just 11 points, and the team shot a collective 36% from the field. The Pacers’ supporting cast, led by Rik Smits’ 10 points, did just enough to provide a defensive foothold while their superstar detonated.

On a night where points were a premium, Reggie Miller was an unstoppable force. He didn’t just win a game; he seized his place in history with one of the most spectacular individual scoring barrages the league has ever witnessed.
